Statement of Academic PurposeKey Criteria for Success
Show you're qualified and a good fit for the program.
Keep it concise: 1-2 pages max (less if required).
Highlight research and internship experiences
What should you do?
Make your match clear: Show how your research
interests align with the program's focus, and those of the
faculty.
Research the program: Understand the departmental
aims and faculty research areas.
Create a academic narrative: Show what drives you as a
researcher and your long-term goals.
Describe your experiences clearly: Focus on specific
accomplishments, research experience, quantified
impact and relevant projects completed 
engineering.princeton.eduRemember: 
This is your chance to stand out— be clear and
show how you'll thrive in graduate school!

Key Criteria for Success
Show you're qualified and a good fit for the program.
Keep it concise: 1-2 pages max (less if required).
Highlight research and internship experiences
What should you NOT do?
Don’t write about others: Keep the focus on YOU and
YOUR RESEARCH INTERESTS, not your role models. It's
about your interests, goals and experience.
Avoid vague descriptions: Use clear, detailed examples
with numbers, not generic phrases like “I worked on a
project…” instead try “I worked on computational
molecular modelling simulation using…”
Don’t repeat your resume: Your statement of purpose
weaves together a narrative of your intellectual and
research journey that highlights a select set of
experiences.

The structure below can help you structure your SOAP.
Simple example:
I am currently studying computer science at X University, and I am
actively involved in a research project that is developing an
automated system to assist archaeologists in reconstructing

More narrative and thematic example (good if the theme
continues to evolve):
I have always had a keen interest in mathematics and physics and
with time it extended into the field of mechanics. Before I knew it, I
was deeply interested in understanding the working of mechanical
systems. It started as a matter of pure curiosity but the more I
researched about it the more I wanted to know and explore this field. Introduction

Drafting your statement
engineering.princeton.eduMy work focuses in particular on analyzing fracture patterns from
images of frescoes and developing a model of brittle fracture. This
project has opened my eyes to a broad range of investigatory
options in computer graphics and motivated me to pursue
graduate studies to deepen my understanding and expertise in
areas of visualization, computational photography, and simulation. What have you
been interested
in?
What did you
do to explore
your interest or
deepen your
knowledge?
Body Paragraph 1
I conducted research that analyzed fracture patterns observed in
frescoes excavated from site C.
I developed a two-stage processing pipeline for this purpose. 
In the first stage, I used an interactive program to trace detailed
fragment boundaries in high-resolution images of manually
reconstructed frescoes. The output was a polygonal mesh, with
each polygon representing a fragment. Next, I implemented
geometric analysis algorithms to study the shapes and contacts of
the fragment boundaries. Specifically, I produced statistical
distributions of the lengths of cracks, the angles at which cracks met,
the fragment areas, and the adjacencies found in fragment
arrangements. 
The main contribution of my study is a statistical model for crack
patterns of fractured frescoes, which can guide scoring functions
used in computer-assisted fragment reconstruction algorithms and
also suggest a generative model about fracture processes.Define

engineering.princeton.eduIn my graduate study, I wish to do research in the area of computer
graphics with broad applications in other disciplines. 
For these reasons, the EECS department at Institution X is especially
attractive to me. I am intrigued by several interesting research projects
carried on by its faculty members. In particular, Professor A’s and
Professor B’s research application in Virtual Humans is fascinating;
their work on “Hair Photobooth: Geometric and Photometric
Acquisition of Real Hairstyles” and C’s work on “A Statistical Model for
Synthesis of Detailed Facial Geometry” were especially interesting to
read.Where do you
